text:
309 (old no. 293) Bleeker Street, northeast side, between Barrow and Grove Street, This was once Mrs. Ryder's house on Herring Street, between Reason and Columbia Streets, to use the contemporary names. Here Thomas Paine, author of "The Age of Reason," spent most of the last year of his life, although he died in another house on Grove (then Columbia) Street, to which he was moved in April 1809. The house shown here will be taken down in 1932.

In 1829 Herring Street became part of Bleeker Street, and was renumbered accordingly; the house numbers were again changed around the time of the Civil War. At that time this house, then 293 Bleeker Street, became 309 Bleeker Street.

Wurts Brothers

August 19, 1914

Bleecker Street, northeast side, north from Seventh Avenue South, across Grove, to Christopher Street's. The two blocks shown are the last of the section that passed thru the former Herring Farm, and was called Herring Street. The triangular block in the foreground exists since the cutting thru of Seventh Avenue in 1915. Antiquated attic structures seen are No's. 305-7 & 309. The latter, formerly No. 293, is the house in which Thomas Paine lived from July, 1808, to April, 1809. At this time Herring Street was newly opened. View No. 2 is of the Doll's House Tea Room located in the tin shack at the apex. Anna Mescia of Grantwood is the property owner and will commission S. Schuman, architect, to design a two story dwelling and store for this site. This is to cost $12,000 as reported in the New York Times of April 27, 1939.

No. 1: 1922
2: Sept. 26, 1928

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection

P. L. Sperr

Bleecker Street, northeast side, north from Seventh Avenue South, across Grove, to Christopher Street's. The two blocks shown are the last of the section that passed thru the former Herring Farm, and was called Herring Street. The triangular block in the foreground exists since the cutting thru of Seventh Avenue in 1915. Antiquated attic structures seen are No's. 305-7 & 309. The latter, formerly No. 293, is the house in which Thomas Paine lived from July, 1808, to April, 1809. At this time Herring Street was newly opened. View No. 2 is of the Doll's House Tea Room located in the tin shack at the apex. Anna Mescia of Grantwood is the property owner and will commission S. Schuman, architect, to design a two story dwelling and store for this site. This is to cost $12,000 as reported in the New York Times of April 27, 1939.

No. 1: 1922
2: Sept. 26, 1928

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection

P. L. Sperr

Bleecker Street, northeast side, north from Seventh Avenue South. The aged buildings appearing in the foreground are No's. 305-7 (a double house) and 309. The latter is the Thomas Paine home of 1808-9. At that date this thoroughfare was known as Herring Street and had just been opened. View No. 2 is slightly earlier and shows the tin garage (No. 303) used as a tea room. No. 3 is still earlier and is in the opposite direction being photographed from a point above Grove Street.

No. 1: Sept. 26, 1928
2: March 28, 1928
3: Oct. 14, 1927

P. L. Sperr

Seventh Avenue South, west side, at Bleeker Street.
March 29, 1928.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

Bleecker Street, at and adjoining the truncated N.E. corner of Barrow Street, on the east side of Seventh Avenue South. Three corners of this intersection were entirely destroyed when Seventh Avenue South was cut through in 1915; the N.W. corner remained intact. August 21, 1929.

P. L. Sperr..

No's. 303, 305-7 & 309 Bleecker Street, northeast side, between Seventh Avenue South and Grove Street, showing two antiquated structures and a tin garage (No. 303). The individual photo is of No. 309, the house in which Thomas Paine resided from July 1808, to April 1809. At this time this thoroughfare was known as Herring Street.
No's. 1-2-3: May 27, 1930
P. L. Sperr

No's. 303, 305-7 & 309 Bleecker Street, northeast side, between Seventh Avenue South and Grove Street, showing two antiquated structures and a tin garage (No. 303). The individual photo is of No. 309, the house in which Thomas Paine resided from July 1808, to April 1809. At this time this thoroughfare was known as Herring Street.
No's. 1-2-3: May 27, 1930
P. L. Sperr

No's. 303, 305-7 & 309 Bleecker Street, northeast side, between Seventh Avenue South and Grove Street, showing two antiquated structures and a tin garage (No. 303). The individual photo is of No. 309, the house in which Thomas Paine resided from July 1808, to April 1809. At this time this thoroughfare was known as Herring Street.
No's. 1-2-3: May 27, 1930
P. L. Sperr

Seventh Avenue South, adjoining and at the S.E. corner of Bleecker Street, the former S.W. corner of Bleecker and Commerce Streets, showing the rear of 286 and 284 (old Nos. 270 and 268) Bleecker Street, the former slightly truncated by the avenue. These are frame houses faced with brick. Nos. 287 and 285, on the north side of Bleecker Street, are also shown. Nos. 289 and 283 are almost entirely off the picture or hidden.

1932.

J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.

Seventh Avenue South, west side, Bleecker to Grove Streets.
March 12, 1933.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

286-280 Bleecker Street, at and adjoining the S.W. corner of Commerce Street, at Seventh Avenue South.
March 29, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

286-280 Bleecker Street, at and adjoining the S.W. corner of Commerce Street, at Seventh Avenue South.
March 29, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

Bleecker Street, north from and including Seventh Avenue South, seen from the eastern end of Commerce Street. At the left, across Seventh Avenue South, is the former N.W. corner of Barrow and Bleecker Streets, the only one of the four corners left intact when Seventh Avenue was cut through in 1915.
March 29, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
